    • Method Detail

      • start

        public void start()
           throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: RdiClient
        Initialize the RdiClient. Must be called before calling send() or flush().
        Specified by:
        start in interface RdiClient<T>
        Throws:
        Exception

      • send

        public void send(T event)
          throws RdiException
        Description copied from interface: RdiClient
        Used to send event messages to the client for batching and posting. "Send" will queue events up and then POST a new batch periodically when the events being buffered reach the max batch event count (flushCount) or the max batch size in bytes (flushBytes). As a result, "send" may block when "flush" occurs.
        Specified by:
        send in interface RdiClient<T>
        Parameters:
        event - event message of generic type to be posted via the client.
        Throws:
        RdiException - - May throw exceptions if your messages fail to serialize (which happens immediately). May also throw exception when flush is triggered if there are connection/network issues, or the client is unable to POST to the server (e.g. if rate limit is exceeded, credentials are incorrect, or server issues)

      • flush

        public void flush()
           throws RdiException
        Description copied from interface: RdiClient
        Calling "flush" will force all pending events to be batched and sent to the server and will block until all events are received by the server. NOTE: you should use "flush" periodically if you want to implement "checkpoint"-oriented logic.
        Specified by:
        flush in interface RdiClient<T>
        Throws:
        RdiException - - Throws exceptions if your messages cannot be posted to the server. Causes for POST failures include connectivity/network issues, IOExceptions, or bad HTTP responses from the server due to issues such as exceeding your rate limit (HTTP 420), incorrect credentials (HTTP 401), or server issues (HTTP 500s). The client will retry with exponential backoff up to the maxRetries that you set in the RdiClientConfig.

      • close

        public void close()
        Description copied from interface: RdiClient
        Signal that event transmission is complete. Close the client. Calling close will not call flush, so that should be done manually before calling close.
        Specified by:
        close in interface RdiClient<T>
